instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used on identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level using Raman spectroscopy?
Output: Raman spectroscopy was used to acquire spectral data for identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used to preprocess the Raman spectra on identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level using Raman spectroscopy?
Output: Savitzky-Golay smoothing (SG), Multivariate Scatter Correction (MSC), Standard Normal Variate (SNV), Hilbert Transform (HT), First-derivative (Derivative) were used as spectral feature processing methods for preprocessing the Raman spectra on identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level using Raman spectroscopy.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the model performance on identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level using Raman spectroscopy, and how well did it perform?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the model performance on identifying Salmonella serotypes at the single-cell level using Raman spectroscopy was accuracy (ACC). Past study found that the combination of Savitzky-Golay smoothing (SG) with Standard Normal Variate (SNV) as the spectral pre-processing method achieved the highest accuracy. The CNN model achieved an accuracy of 98.7% for the training set and over 98.5% for the test set using this pre-processing method.

instruction: What were the evaluation indicators used to assess the performance of the CNN model in predicting Salmonella serotypes using Raman spectroscopy?
Output: The evaluation indicators used to assess the performance of the CNN model in predicting Salmonella serotypes using Raman spectroscopy were Accuracy (ACC), Precision, Recall, and F1-score.

instruction: Can the combination of Savitzky-Golay smoothing and Standard Normal Variate (SG+SNV) be considered a superior spectral pre-processing method for identifying Salmonella serotypes using Raman spectroscopy, compared to traditional methods?
Output: Yes, the combination of Savitzky-Golay smoothing and Standard Normal Variate (SG+SNV) can be considered a superior spectral pre-processing method for identifying Salmonella serotypes using Raman spectroscopy, compared to traditional methods. According to past study, SG+SNV achieved an accuracy of 98.7% for the training set and over 98.5% for the test set in the convolutional neural network (CNN) model. This method outperformed other spectral pre-processing methods, indicating its effectiveness in predicting Salmonella serotypes. Therefore, SG+SNV can be considered a superior method for identifying Salmonella serotypes using Raman spectroscopy.
